page.title: 05Potterspury Church Belltower
page.content: At one end of St Nicholas Church, Potterspury is a square stone tower containing six bells. The oldest of these was made in 1480. The bells are worked from the ground floor by ropes going through the ceiling. Up one side of the tower is a stone spiral staircase and this leads right up to the roof. On the first floor in the tower you can see an extremely fine clock mechanism worked by heavy weights which have to be wound up once a week. In the actual bell room you can see the six bells with their large wooden wheels by their side. The bell can also be rung by metal strikers if there is only one bell ringer. In 1985 the top part of the tower was restored and many fund-raising events have taken place to raise money for the project including a sponsored 'Hush' by the school children.
